msgSnippet: You are right.  And as I recall, we have tested for that case in our code as well.  How would the framework know when to use a comparator or not?  Have

To: "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: RE: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test
Date: Wed, 25 Jul 2001 14:28:43 -0400
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2653.19)
X-WSS-ID: 1741D05558386-01-01
Content-Type: text/plain;  charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>

You are right.  And as I recall, we have tested for that case in our code as
well.  How would the framework know when to use a comparator or not?  Have
something like the following?  Seems quirky... but this is what working on 4
hours of sleep can do :)

assertEquals(expectedCollection, actualCollection)
assertComparesGreaterThanZero(expectedCollection, actualCollection)
assertComparesLessThanZero(expectedCollection, actualCollection)
assertComparesZero(expectedCollection, actualCollection)

-Jason

    > -----Original Message-----
    > From: Vladimir Bossicard [mailto:vladimir@...]
    > Sent: Wednesday, July 25, 2001 12:36 PM
    > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
    > Subject: Re: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed 
    > assertion per test
    > 
    > 
    > >
    > >
    > >How would this complete list help you any more than the 
    > simple fact that the
    > >arrays were not of the same length?  Given that I 
    > expected them to contain
    > >the same number of elements, the most valuable 
    > information to me would be
    > >that they were of different lengths, not which elements 
    > were/were not
    > >present.
    > >
    > I partially don't agree.  I think that comparing vectors 
    > should tell you 
    > if the elements are equals.  If your testing a sort 
    > algorythm, you want 
    > to know if elements of the result vector are in the right 
    > position. 
    >  This request (assertEquals do array properly) has been 
    > expressed by 
    > many people and I think that it should be included in JUnit.
    > 
    > But I'm against the "soft warning" idea.  Don't see the 
    > added value there.
    > 
    > -Vladimir

subject: RE: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test
